lines.text: What noisy people! I've never seen noise and boredom go so well together.
Oh I don't know, Uncle Homer lived here for 40 years without getting bored.
Uncle Homer was not a normal person.
[last lines]
Tell me. I want to hear you say it.
Alright, I love you.
He wrote some beautiful verses.
I'll buy his books.
He never published them. You think a young poet can find a publisher?
So how do you know them?

He would read to me, and I copied many of them down. "Temple of the spirit. No longer bodies, but pure, ascetic images, compare to which thought itself becomes leaden, opaque, heavy." He wrote those verses here in Italy, during the war.
[first lines]
Where are we?
Oh, I don't know exactly.
I wanted you to take a rest. It didn't occur to me that it'd be so boring for you to be alone with me.
What's that got to do with it? I'm just bored because I've got nothing to do.
This is the first time that we've been really alone ever since we married.
Yes, I suppose it is.
Are you sure you know when I'm happy?
No, ever since we left on this trip I'm not so sure. I realised for the first time that we... we're like strangers.
That's right. After eight years of marriage, it seems like we don't know anything about each other.
At home everything seemed so perfect, but now that we're away, alone...
Yes, it's a strange discovery to make.
We English aren't allowed to enjoy long stays abroad.
Where did we meet him?
At the Smith's house.
Was he an attorney?
No. No. A poet. He was slender, blond, tall, so delicate and romantic.
Your compliment hides the usual veiled criticism, the "dolce far niente."
No, not at all.
How do you say "dolce far niente" in English?
I think they use the Italian phrase, but I think you could translate it as "how sweet to do nothing."
They say all Neapolitans are indolent. But you tell me, can you call a castaway indolent? In a way, we're all castaways. We have to fight so hard just to stay afloat.
I would say it's a very pleasurable shipwreck.
Especially when I look into your eyes, stars in the night.
Ha-ha-ha...
I can't stand this damn country anymore. The idleness is toxic.
What did Charles's cough tell you?
That he was a fool.
He was not a fool. He was a poet.
What's the difference?
